attributes.title: Information Distortion and Choice Structure
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

question2a.value:
Between subjects: There are three experimental choice conditions and a control condition. The three experimental choice conditions include an early choice condition, an early choice removed condition, and a late choice condition. 
Within Subjects: Choice domain (apartments and cars), order of attributes (random within each half of the experimental conditions), order of choice domain (e.g., apartments first).
Because we were concerned with carry-over effects from the choice being removed from certain participants, the early choice and early choice removed conditions only contain one of the domains. For these two conditions, the order of the attributes is still counterbalanced, but there is no counterbalancing of the order of the choice domain because they are only evaluating information for one of the domains.

question2b.value: Amount of distortion calculated using Russo et al.’s (1996, 1998) leader-signed distortion metric. We will also compute a metric based on what the participant chose in the early choice condition (choice-signed distortion), and a metric based on distortion towards the alternative that was chosen for them in the early choice removal condition. Overall, distortion will be calculated for the currently leading alternative, and for the participants where there was an early choice or early choice removal, we will also calculate distortion based on the choice (or removed choice).

question3b.value: Block: Two blocks: before and after the halfway point. This is important because some participants will continue the decision task as usual, some will make a choice between the two alternatives half-way through, and some will have that choice taken away and be assigned one of the alternatives half-way through.

question10b.value:
In this study, we will use three choice conditions (i.e., early choice, early choice removed, and late choice) and one control condition. In addition, we will also use two choice domains (i.e., apartment and cars). Because of concerns of carry-over effects, those in the early choice and early choice removal conditions will make judgments for only one of the two domains (assigned randomly) and those in the late choice and control condition will make judgments about both of the domains. Participants will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 different attributes for each domain. The attributes that the participants will be judging will be quantitative and diagnostic in nature (e.g., highway MPG, apartment square footage). Each pair will focus on one attribute and highlight how the two apartments or cars differ in that attribute. For example, participants might see a pair of attributes that states that Car A gets 42 highway miles per gallons and Car B gets 38 highway miles per gallon. The survey itself will be run on Qualtrics and will use Ohio State University’s psychology participation pool. The order is random within each block of the 20 attributes is randomly determined (based on block), and both domains assigned, and domain order are also randomly assigned. 
There are two blocks. Each block contains 10 sets of attributes. The order of the attributes is randomly shown within each block. For subjects who only see one domain, they will be randomly assigned to either cars or apartments. For those who see both domains, the order in which they evaluate cars vs apartments will be randomized.  
Participants will be assigned to one of six conditions (described above in the planned sample size section). For those in the control condition, participants will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 different attributes for two different alternatives per domain. On each page, there will be one attribute per alternative, and each of the 20 sets of attributes will be displayed on separate pages. They will be told that they are not being asked to make a choice, and to evaluate the attributes based solely on their appeal. In order to ensure that tentative preferences cannot bias evaluations, for each attribute, the two alternative will be anonymous, such that the identity of the two alternatives will change for each attribute evaluated (e.g., attribute one will display information about Option A and Option B, and another attribute will display information about Option C and Option D). After participants judge the appeal of the 20 sets of attributes for the first domain, they will do the same thing for the second domain. They will then be debriefed, answer a few demographic questions, and thanked for their participation. 
For those assigned to one of the three choice conditions (i.e., early choice, early choice removed, and late choice), they will be asked to make a choice between two alternatives. For those in the early choice condition, they will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 sets of attributes for the two alternatives. For each attribute, participants will be asked two questions. First, they will be asked how appealing or unappealing this specific feature of the apartment or car is for each of the different options. They will respond to these questions on a 9-point scale from very unappealing to very appealing. Next, they will be asked to use the information they have seen up to that point to indicate how much they are leaning towards one apartment/car or the other, using a 10-point scale from strongly leaning towards one option to strongly leaning towards the other option. 
The early choice condition: After they have evaluated 10 attributes, they will be asked to make a choice between the two alternatives. After they have indicated their choice, they will then continue to evaluate the remaining 10 attributes. After they have finished evaluating all 20 sets of attributes, they will be asked to make a final choice, based on all of the attributes they have seen. They will then be asked a few demographic questions, be debriefed, and thanked for their participation. Because of potential carry-over effects, those assigned to this condition will only evaluate attribute for one of the two domains (i.e., either apartments or cars).
The early choice removed condition will be identical to the early choice condition, except for one important feature. For those in the early choice removed condition, after they have rated the 10 attributes, they will be told that one of the alternatives is no longer available (which of the two alternatives removed is determined randomly). For example, if the participant was making judgments about the two apartments, halfway through the procedure they would be told that one of the apartments has been leased, therefore they have been assigned to lease the remaining apartment. After this choice removal halfway, they will continue evaluating the remaining 10 attributes in the same way that they evaluated the first 10. In other words, even though the participant has now been assigned one of the alternatives, they will continue to evaluate information for both of the alternatives. At the end of the procedure, they will be asked to make a choice between the two alternatives as if both were still available. Because of potential carry-over effects, those assigned to this condition will only evaluate attribute for one of the two domains (i.e., either apartments or cars).
The late choice condition will also be very similar to the early choice and early choice removed condition. For instance, they will be asked to evaluate the 20 sets of attributes for the two alternatives, and then asked to make a choice at the end. The most important difference for this condition is that there is no halfway choice or choice removal. Those in this condition will rate each of the 20 attributes, uninterrupted, and then make a final choice between the two alternatives at the end of the study. Because there is no “surprise” choice or choice removal, those assigned to this condition will make judgments for both of the domains.
All will end with demographic questions, will be asked about their ideas about a potential hypothesis of the study, and be debriefed.

question4b.value: Those enrolled in an introductory psychology course at Ohio State University.

question5b.value: Student participant pool of psychology students from Ohio State University.

question6b.value:
The planned sample size is ~450. This number was determined using the following group distinctions:
75 for the apartment domain and early choice removal condition
75 for the cars domain and early choice removal condition
75 for the apartment domain and the early choice condition
75 for the cars domain and the early choice condition
75 for the late choice condition (this condition evaluates attributes from both of the domains)
75 for the control condition (this condition evaluates attributes from both of the domains
75*6 = 450 participants

question7b.value: We will end termination once we have reached at least 10% more than 450 participants (i.e., ~500 participants) in order to account for possible exclusions based on the criteria listed below. In addition, because the participants are Ohio State psychology students, data collection may have to end when the semester ends.

question8b.value: For each attribute there are three questions, one question asking about the appeal of the attribute for Option A, one questions asking about the appeal of the attribute for Option B, and one question asking the participant if they are leaning towards one option over another. If a participant skips any of the questions for more than two attributes, then they will be removed.

question7c.value: Listwise deletion for all individuals who did not answer more than two of the attribute rating questions. For those participants judging both domains (late choice and control), data will only be deleted for the domain where they did not answer more than two of the attribute ratings. If they satisfied the requirement for the other domain, those data will be kept in the dataset. Refer to the exclusion criteria for our guidelines on handling missing data.

question1a.value:
1.	For the first half of the experiment, we do not expect any differences in information distortion between the choice conditions, but we do expect distortion scores to be greater than 0, indicating distortion in favor of the currently leading alternative. 
2.	We want to compare the early choice condition to the late choice condition. In the case of post-choice bolstering, we predict that there will be distortion in favor of the leading alternative after the halfway choice (though it is possible that it will be less distortion because of past research on post-choice distortion). 
3.	We predict that there will also be post-“chosen for them” bolstering (i.e., coping) in favor of the option chosen for them. For those in the early choice removed condition, the goal ultimately depends on if the participants were given the option they were leaning towards prior to the halfway point.
4.	After the halfway point of the three experimental conditions (i.e., late choice, early choice, and early choice removed), people in the late choice condition will distort in favor of the currently leading alternative, people in the early choice condition will distort in favor of the choice made at the halfway point, and the people in the early choice removal condition will distort in favor of the currently available alternative.

question2a.value: Information distortion will depend on the choice condition. Before the halfway point, there should be no difference in information distortion. For after the halfway mark, information distortion will be smaller for the early-choice condition than for the late-choice condition. In order to calculate information distortion for those who made the choice halfway through the procedure, we will calculate distortion not only based on the current leading alternative (leader-signed distortion), but also distortion based on the choice made at the halfway point (what we will henceforth call choice-signed distortion). In the early choice removal condition, we will calculate distortion much in the same way, one way using the current leading alternative and another using the choice that was made for them. However, in addition, we will also calculate distortion based on the leading alternative prior to the choice removal.

question3a.value: We have not included any manipulation checks in this study. We do include a question at the end of the experiment asking the participant if they have any guesses to the hypotheses or purpose of the study, but this does not necessarily check our manipulations.

question5a.value:
Information Distortion: 
When making a decision, people form a tentative preference. This preference shifts their evaluation of new information (DeKay, Miller, Schley, & Erford, 2014). The evaluation of the new information tends to be in favor of the preferred alternative (pro-leader distortion) and against the non-preferred alternative (antitrailer distortion). This in turn causes a cycle where biased evaluation of new information maintains or strengthens the preference which leads to further biased evaluation of new information. This is referred to as predecisional information distortion (Russo, Medvec, & Meloy, 1996; Russo, Meloy, & Medvec, 1998). Information distortion can happen even in the absence of a previous preference (i.e., the preference can form spontaneously during the task) and tends to shrink by about half after a decision has been made (Russo et al., 1996). Predecisional distortion can happen in a variety of contexts, including real-estate decisions (DeKay et al., 2014; DeKay, 2015), medical decisions (Kostopoulou, Russo, Keenan, Delaney, Douiri, 2012; Levy & Hershey, 2006), and consumer decisions (Bond, Carlson, Russo, & Tanner, 2007; Carlson et al., 2006; Russo et al., 1996, 1998; Russo, Carlson, Meloy, & Yong, 2008). Distortion can happen with or without incentives (Meloy, Russo, & Miller, 2006), when preference is experimentally manipulated (Russo et al., 1996, 1998), and when the information about the alternatives is non-diagnostic (Russo et al., 1996, 1998). Importantly, distortion has also been shown to predict final choice (DeKay et al., 2014). Predecisional information distortion was discovered as a byproduct of Festinger’s 1957 work on cognitive dissonance. At the time, the lack of strong evidence for predecisional distortion led Festinger to focus solely on postdecisional distortion. However, since then, researchers have strived to investigate why information distortion occurs. In a group of studies, researchers found that certain primes affected the degree of information distortion (Russo, Carlson, Meloy, Margaret & Yong, 2008). Specifically, they found that when participants were primed with consistency and coherence, this led to the greatest degree of predecisional information distortion, as compared to primes relating to reducing cognitive effort, separating alternatives. In other words, it is theorized that the reason information distortion occurs is because people have a need to create and maintain consistency in their preferences and judgments. In turn, when a tentative preference is formed, the combination of that tentative preference with the desire for coherence allows the person to distort information in favor of the leading alternative, while discounting information about the trialing alternative. A consistent factor in all information distortion research is that the participant has a choice between alternatives. Sometimes the timing of the choice is at their discretion (Russo et al., 1998), and sometimes the choice is at the end of the task (DeKay et al., 2014), but throughout all work in this paradigm, there have yet to be experimental manipulations where the participant is not given a choice between the two alternatives. More importantly, there has yet to be research investigating information distortion when the choice is removed from the participant. Because distortion research makes no claims about behavior when choice is removed, I discuss research in other similar domains that may shed light on people’s potential behavior. 
Coping and Rationalization: 
Research has shown that people consistently avoid feeling the negative feelings of a situation that they know is immutable. For instance, prizes are evaluated as less desirable if they are not won (Kahneman, Knetch, & Thaler, 1990, 1991), high school students judge colleges more negatively after rejection (Lyubomirsky & Ross, 1999), voters judge the winner of an election more favorably even if they were originally opposed (Gilbert et at., 1998), and smokers say a smoking ban will affect them less when surveyed after it takes effect (Laurin, 2018). Overall, evaluation of a negative event improves after it happens. This happens only in events that can’t be changed. This is thought to occur because it puts people in a more “emotion-focused coping” versus a “problem-focused coping” frame of mind. In summary, information-distortion theory doesn’t make any claims about what happens when the participant isn’t given a choice. Coping research could potentially claim that people’s evaluation of the information about the forced alternative that they are given would improve once the other alternative is removed.  However, rationalization and coping theory appear to address only general attitudes and evaluations and do not speak to the specific process by which people form positive evaluations. Information distortion may be a mechanism that explains such favorable evaluations.

question6a.value: The consistency account for information distortion (Russo et al., 2008) is silent about what would happen if there is no choice because an option is externally imposed. Ultimately, it depends on what was the preferred option before the choice removal, the goal of the participant, and whether or not that goal has been satisfied. For instance, if the participant’s goal is to remain consistent with their early tentative preference, then removing one of the alternatives (thereby making the choice for the participant) should have no effect because they would wish to continue distorting towards the leading alternative. However, if the participant’s goal is to reduce the negative feelings associated with not getting the preferred alternative, then the participant may start to distort information in favor of the alternative that was chosen for them. If in the choice removal condition the participant got the option they were already leaning towards, then no special predictions are made about their distortion after this point. However, if the participant was given the option they were not leaning towards, then it could depend on the overall goal of the participant to either bolster their leading alternative prior to removal, or reduce the negative feelings of being given the non-preferred option. This study will explore all of these combinations. Depending on the results of this first study, it may be useful to understand the mechanism behind distortion when the choice is made for the participant to determine if Russo’s consistency explanation is a valid explanation in this context.

question1c.value:
In order to test our hypotheses, there are three metrics that will be calculated: leader-signed distortion, choice-signed distortion, and choice removed-signed distortion.
Leader-signed distortion: We will use the metric outlined in Russo et al. (1998). In order to compute this score, we subtract Option B’s appeal rating from Option A’s appeal rating (this is done for each attribute for each participant). This gives us an indication of how much more appealing Option B was compared to Option A. In order to assess distortion, we average the control group’s B-A difference scores (because the options were anonymous and therefore unbiased and can be used as a baseline). We subtract those baseline difference scores from the experimental participants’ B-A difference scores. We do this for each attribute for each participant. Higher scores indicate favoring Option B, and lower scores indicate favoring Option A. We then determine which option was leading at the previously evaluated alternative. If the participant was leaning towards Option B, then the score is left alone. If the participant was leaning towards Option A, then the sign of the score is flipped. The result of this is that positive scores favor what was leading, and negative scores favor what was trailing. This gives us a distortion score for each attribute for each participant. We then average across the attributes for each participant, by block. This gives us an average amount of distortion before the halfway point and an average amount of distortion after the halfway point. 
Choice-signed distortion: This distortion score will be calculated much like leader-signed distortion. The only difference is instead of flipping the sign of the distortion in favor of the leading alternative, we use what choice the participant made at the halfway point as an indicator. 
Choice removal-signed distortion will use the option that was chosen for them as an indicator. 
4.	For the first half of the experiment, we will use the leader-signed distortion calculation to determine if distortion is positive (which would indicate that people distort information towards their leading alternative). We do not expect any differences between the choice conditions in the first half of the experiment. 
5.	For the second half of the experiment, we will calculate distortion three different ways. For all of the three choice conditions, distortion will be calculated based on the currently leading alternative. For the early choice condition, we will also calculate distortion based on the choice made at the halfway point. For the early choice removed condition, we will also calculate distortion based on the alternative that was chosen for them, as well as the alternative that was preferred before the halfway point. 
6.	Because we do not predict any differences in distortion in the first half of the experiment (i.e., where all participants are essentially doing the same thing) the remainder of these analyses refer to the second block of the experiment, and are thus interactions with the block condition. 
7.	We want to compare the early choice condition to the late choice condition. We predict that there will be a post choice decrease in information distortion for those in the early choice condition. We will calculate this difference using the standard leader-signed distortion metric. In other words, the late choice condition will have roughly equal amounts of distortion before and after the halfway point, and the early choice condition will have less distortion after the halfway point (compared to both the late choice second block distortion and the early choice first block distortion).
8.	For the second half of the experiment,
a.	Those in the late choice condition will distort in favor of the currently leading alternative (calculated using the leader-signed distortion metric).
b.	Those in the early choice condition will distort in favor of the choice that was made at the halfway point (calculated using the choice-signed distortion metric).
c.	Those in the early choice removed condition will distort in favor of the choice that was made for them (calculated using the choice removed-signed distortion metric). For those in this condition, we understand that in some cases the participant was given what they wanted, and in some cases, they were not given what they wanted. We will explore distortion for both the choice that was made for them as well as distortion in favor of what was leading before the choice was made for them. However, we do not have predictions for how participants in this condition will differ.
9.	We will compare amount of distortion in the first and second half for those in the late choice condition, to determine if distortion increases or decreases over time, but we do not have predictions for this analysis.
Once we have an overall average distortion score for each individual, we can then conduct the tests to investigate the hypotheses stated above. We plan on using mixed linear regression with an individual’s aggregated distortion score as the dependent variable, and choice condition, block, domain, and domain order as the main predictor variables. We also plan to use paired samples t-tests to compare distortion for each participant before and after the halfway point.

question3c.value:
IV: choice condition.
DV: information distortion.
Moderator: block.

registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question5a:
Information Distortion: 
When making a decision, people form a tentative preference. This preference shifts their evaluation of new information (DeKay, Miller, Schley, & Erford, 2014). The evaluation of the new information tends to be in favor of the preferred alternative (pro-leader distortion) and against the non-preferred alternative (antitrailer distortion). This in turn causes a cycle where biased evaluation of new information maintains or strengthens the preference which leads to further biased evaluation of new information. This is referred to as predecisional information distortion (Russo, Medvec, & Meloy, 1996; Russo, Meloy, & Medvec, 1998). Information distortion can happen even in the absence of a previous preference (i.e., the preference can form spontaneously during the task) and tends to shrink by about half after a decision has been made (Russo et al., 1996). Predecisional distortion can happen in a variety of contexts, including real-estate decisions (DeKay et al., 2014; DeKay, 2015), medical decisions (Kostopoulou, Russo, Keenan, Delaney, Douiri, 2012; Levy & Hershey, 2006), and consumer decisions (Bond, Carlson, Russo, & Tanner, 2007; Carlson et al., 2006; Russo et al., 1996, 1998; Russo, Carlson, Meloy, & Yong, 2008). Distortion can happen with or without incentives (Meloy, Russo, & Miller, 2006), when preference is experimentally manipulated (Russo et al., 1996, 1998), and when the information about the alternatives is non-diagnostic (Russo et al., 1996, 1998). Importantly, distortion has also been shown to predict final choice (DeKay et al., 2014). Predecisional information distortion was discovered as a byproduct of Festinger’s 1957 work on cognitive dissonance. At the time, the lack of strong evidence for predecisional distortion led Festinger to focus solely on postdecisional distortion. However, since then, researchers have strived to investigate why information distortion occurs. In a group of studies, researchers found that certain primes affected the degree of information distortion (Russo, Carlson, Meloy, Margaret & Yong, 2008). Specifically, they found that when participants were primed with consistency and coherence, this led to the greatest degree of predecisional information distortion, as compared to primes relating to reducing cognitive effort, separating alternatives. In other words, it is theorized that the reason information distortion occurs is because people have a need to create and maintain consistency in their preferences and judgments. In turn, when a tentative preference is formed, the combination of that tentative preference with the desire for coherence allows the person to distort information in favor of the leading alternative, while discounting information about the trialing alternative. A consistent factor in all information distortion research is that the participant has a choice between alternatives. Sometimes the timing of the choice is at their discretion (Russo et al., 1998), and sometimes the choice is at the end of the task (DeKay et al., 2014), but throughout all work in this paradigm, there have yet to be experimental manipulations where the participant is not given a choice between the two alternatives. More importantly, there has yet to be research investigating information distortion when the choice is removed from the participant. Because distortion research makes no claims about behavior when choice is removed, I discuss research in other similar domains that may shed light on people’s potential behavior. 
Coping and Rationalization: 
Research has shown that people consistently avoid feeling the negative feelings of a situation that they know is immutable. For instance, prizes are evaluated as less desirable if they are not won (Kahneman, Knetch, & Thaler, 1990, 1991), high school students judge colleges more negatively after rejection (Lyubomirsky & Ross, 1999), voters judge the winner of an election more favorably even if they were originally opposed (Gilbert et at., 1998), and smokers say a smoking ban will affect them less when surveyed after it takes effect (Laurin, 2018). Overall, evaluation of a negative event improves after it happens. This happens only in events that can’t be changed. This is thought to occur because it puts people in a more “emotion-focused coping” versus a “problem-focused coping” frame of mind. In summary, information-distortion theory doesn’t make any claims about what happens when the participant isn’t given a choice. Coping research could potentially claim that people’s evaluation of the information about the forced alternative that they are given would improve once the other alternative is removed.  However, rationalization and coping theory appear to address only general attitudes and evaluations and do not speak to the specific process by which people form positive evaluations. Information distortion may be a mechanism that explains such favorable evaluations.
registration_responses.recommended-hypothesis.question6a: The consistency account for information distortion (Russo et al., 2008) is silent about what would happen if there is no choice because an option is externally imposed. Ultimately, it depends on what was the preferred option before the choice removal, the goal of the participant, and whether or not that goal has been satisfied. For instance, if the participant’s goal is to remain consistent with their early tentative preference, then removing one of the alternatives (thereby making the choice for the participant) should have no effect because they would wish to continue distorting towards the leading alternative. However, if the participant’s goal is to reduce the negative feelings associated with not getting the preferred alternative, then the participant may start to distort information in favor of the alternative that was chosen for them. If in the choice removal condition the participant got the option they were already leaning towards, then no special predictions are made about their distortion after this point. However, if the participant was given the option they were not leaning towards, then it could depend on the overall goal of the participant to either bolster their leading alternative prior to removal, or reduce the negative feelings of being given the non-preferred option. This study will explore all of these combinations. Depending on the results of this first study, it may be useful to understand the mechanism behind distortion when the choice is made for the participant to determine if Russo’s consistency explanation is a valid explanation in this context.

registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
In this study, we will use three choice conditions (i.e., early choice, early choice removed, and late choice) and one control condition. In addition, we will also use two choice domains (i.e., apartment and cars). Because of concerns of carry-over effects, those in the early choice and early choice removal conditions will make judgments for only one of the two domains (assigned randomly) and those in the late choice and control condition will make judgments about both of the domains. Participants will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 different attributes for each domain. The attributes that the participants will be judging will be quantitative and diagnostic in nature (e.g., highway MPG, apartment square footage). Each pair will focus on one attribute and highlight how the two apartments or cars differ in that attribute. For example, participants might see a pair of attributes that states that Car A gets 42 highway miles per gallons and Car B gets 38 highway miles per gallon. The survey itself will be run on Qualtrics and will use Ohio State University’s psychology participation pool. The order is random within each block of the 20 attributes is randomly determined (based on block), and both domains assigned, and domain order are also randomly assigned. 
There are two blocks. Each block contains 10 sets of attributes. The order of the attributes is randomly shown within each block. For subjects who only see one domain, they will be randomly assigned to either cars or apartments. For those who see both domains, the order in which they evaluate cars vs apartments will be randomized.  
Participants will be assigned to one of six conditions (described above in the planned sample size section). For those in the control condition, participants will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 different attributes for two different alternatives per domain. On each page, there will be one attribute per alternative, and each of the 20 sets of attributes will be displayed on separate pages. They will be told that they are not being asked to make a choice, and to evaluate the attributes based solely on their appeal. In order to ensure that tentative preferences cannot bias evaluations, for each attribute, the two alternative will be anonymous, such that the identity of the two alternatives will change for each attribute evaluated (e.g., attribute one will display information about Option A and Option B, and another attribute will display information about Option C and Option D). After participants judge the appeal of the 20 sets of attributes for the first domain, they will do the same thing for the second domain. They will then be debriefed, answer a few demographic questions, and thanked for their participation. 
For those assigned to one of the three choice conditions (i.e., early choice, early choice removed, and late choice), they will be asked to make a choice between two alternatives. For those in the early choice condition, they will be asked to judge the appeal of 20 sets of attributes for the two alternatives. For each attribute, participants will be asked two questions. First, they will be asked how appealing or unappealing this specific feature of the apartment or car is for each of the different options. They will respond to these questions on a 9-point scale from very unappealing to very appealing. Next, they will be asked to use the information they have seen up to that point to indicate how much they are leaning towards one apartment/car or the other, using a 10-point scale from strongly leaning towards one option to strongly leaning towards the other option. 
The early choice condition: After they have evaluated 10 attributes, they will be asked to make a choice between the two alternatives. After they have indicated their choice, they will then continue to evaluate the remaining 10 attributes. After they have finished evaluating all 20 sets of attributes, they will be asked to make a final choice, based on all of the attributes they have seen. They will then be asked a few demographic questions, be debriefed, and thanked for their participation. Because of potential carry-over effects, those assigned to this condition will only evaluate attribute for one of the two domains (i.e., either apartments or cars).
The early choice removed condition will be identical to the early choice condition, except for one important feature. For those in the early choice removed condition, after they have rated the 10 attributes, they will be told that one of the alternatives is no longer available (which of the two alternatives removed is determined randomly). For example, if the participant was making judgments about the two apartments, halfway through the procedure they would be told that one of the apartments has been leased, therefore they have been assigned to lease the remaining apartment. After this choice removal halfway, they will continue evaluating the remaining 10 attributes in the same way that they evaluated the first 10. In other words, even though the participant has now been assigned one of the alternatives, they will continue to evaluate information for both of the alternatives. At the end of the procedure, they will be asked to make a choice between the two alternatives as if both were still available. Because of potential carry-over effects, those assigned to this condition will only evaluate attribute for one of the two domains (i.e., either apartments or cars).
The late choice condition will also be very similar to the early choice and early choice removed condition. For instance, they will be asked to evaluate the 20 sets of attributes for the two alternatives, and then asked to make a choice at the end. The most important difference for this condition is that there is no halfway choice or choice removal. Those in this condition will rate each of the 20 attributes, uninterrupted, and then make a final choice between the two alternatives at the end of the study. Because there is no “surprise” choice or choice removal, those assigned to this condition will make judgments for both of the domains.
All will end with demographic questions, will be asked about their ideas about a potential hypothesis of the study, and be debriefed.
registration_responses.confirmatory-analyses-first.first.questi:
In order to test our hypotheses, there are three metrics that will be calculated: leader-signed distortion, choice-signed distortion, and choice removed-signed distortion.
Leader-signed distortion: We will use the metric outlined in Russo et al. (1998). In order to compute this score, we subtract Option B’s appeal rating from Option A’s appeal rating (this is done for each attribute for each participant). This gives us an indication of how much more appealing Option B was compared to Option A. In order to assess distortion, we average the control group’s B-A difference scores (because the options were anonymous and therefore unbiased and can be used as a baseline). We subtract those baseline difference scores from the experimental participants’ B-A difference scores. We do this for each attribute for each participant. Higher scores indicate favoring Option B, and lower scores indicate favoring Option A. We then determine which option was leading at the previously evaluated alternative. If the participant was leaning towards Option B, then the score is left alone. If the participant was leaning towards Option A, then the sign of the score is flipped. The result of this is that positive scores favor what was leading, and negative scores favor what was trailing. This gives us a distortion score for each attribute for each participant. We then average across the attributes for each participant, by block. This gives us an average amount of distortion before the halfway point and an average amount of distortion after the halfway point. 
Choice-signed distortion: This distortion score will be calculated much like leader-signed distortion. The only difference is instead of flipping the sign of the distortion in favor of the leading alternative, we use what choice the participant made at the halfway point as an indicator. 
Choice removal-signed distortion will use the option that was chosen for them as an indicator. 
4.	For the first half of the experiment, we will use the leader-signed distortion calculation to determine if distortion is positive (which would indicate that people distort information towards their leading alternative). We do not expect any differences between the choice conditions in the first half of the experiment. 
5.	For the second half of the experiment, we will calculate distortion three different ways. For all of the three choice conditions, distortion will be calculated based on the currently leading alternative. For the early choice condition, we will also calculate distortion based on the choice made at the halfway point. For the early choice removed condition, we will also calculate distortion based on the alternative that was chosen for them, as well as the alternative that was preferred before the halfway point. 
6.	Because we do not predict any differences in distortion in the first half of the experiment (i.e., where all participants are essentially doing the same thing) the remainder of these analyses refer to the second block of the experiment, and are thus interactions with the block condition. 
7.	We want to compare the early choice condition to the late choice condition. We predict that there will be a post choice decrease in information distortion for those in the early choice condition. We will calculate this difference using the standard leader-signed distortion metric. In other words, the late choice condition will have roughly equal amounts of distortion before and after the halfway point, and the early choice condition will have less distortion after the halfway point (compared to both the late choice second block distortion and the early choice first block distortion).
8.	For the second half of the experiment,
a.	Those in the late choice condition will distort in favor of the currently leading alternative (calculated using the leader-signed distortion metric).
b.	Those in the early choice condition will distort in favor of the choice that was made at the halfway point (calculated using the choice-signed distortion metric).
c.	Those in the early choice removed condition will distort in favor of the choice that was made for them (calculated using the choice removed-signed distortion metric). For those in this condition, we understand that in some cases the participant was given what they wanted, and in some cases, they were not given what they wanted. We will explore distortion for both the choice that was made for them as well as distortion in favor of what was leading before the choice was made for them. However, we do not have predictions for how participants in this condition will differ.
9.	We will compare amount of distortion in the first and second half for those in the late choice condition, to determine if distortion increases or decreases over time, but we do not have predictions for this analysis.
Once we have an overall average distortion score for each individual, we can then conduct the tests to investigate the hypotheses stated above. We plan on using mixed linear regression with an individual’s aggregated distortion score as the dependent variable, and choice condition, block, domain, and domain order as the main predictor variables. We also plan to use paired samples t-tests to compare distortion for each participant before and after the halfway point.

IV: choice condition.
DV: information distortion.
Moderator: block.
registration_responses.description-methods.planned-sample.quest: Those enrolled in an introductory psychology course at Ohio State University.
Student participant pool of psychology students from Ohio State University.

The planned sample size is ~450. This number was determined using the following group distinctions:
75 for the apartment domain and early choice removal condition
75 for the cars domain and early choice removal condition
75 for the apartment domain and the early choice condition
75 for the cars domain and the early choice condition
75 for the late choice condition (this condition evaluates attributes from both of the domains)
75 for the control condition (this condition evaluates attributes from both of the domains
75*6 = 450 participants

We will end termination once we have reached at least 10% more than 450 participants (i.e., ~500 participants) in order to account for possible exclusions based on the criteria listed below. In addition, because the participants are Ohio State psychology students, data collection may have to end when the semester ends.
registration_responses.description-methods.exclusion-criteria.q: For each attribute there are three questions, one question asking about the appeal of the attribute for Option A, one questions asking about the appeal of the attribute for Option B, and one question asking the participant if they are leaning towards one option over another. If a participant skips any of the questions for more than two attributes, then they will be removed.

attributes.title: Reducing Prejudice through Self-Affirmation
attributes.description: Research suggests that self-affirmation can reduce threat in a multitude of domains (e.g., stereotype threat). Given the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce threats to the self of various types, the current work examines the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce outgroup prejudice, and the mechanisms which explain this effect.

q2.value:
Participants engaged in self-affirmation will report lower levels of outgroup prejudice as compared to a control condition (Hypothesis I). 

Intergroup anxiety will mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and prejudice: those in the self-affirmation condition will show lower levels of intergroup anxiety as compared to those in the control condition, and higher levels of intergroup anxiety will be associated with higher levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis II).

Self-compassion will mediate the effect of self-affirmation on prejudice. Specifically, those in the self-affirmation condition will show higher levels of self-compassion as compared to those in the control condition; in addition, higher levels of self-compassion will be associated with lower levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis III).

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will use a between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Participants will also be asked to answer questions measuring the mediating variables (intergroup anxiety and self-compassion). In addition, participants will be assessed for attitudes toward Muslims. Upon completion of the study, participants will be debriefed, thanked, and compensated online.

q7.value: Block randomization will be used, set up using the Randomizer in Qualtrics survey flow. An embedded data item (condition) will be entered to assign participants to the self-affirmation or control condition.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: An original version of this study was preregistered and data collection began on 3/18/2020. The original sample size was 660 Ps paid $0.30 per participant on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Data collection was slow and suggested payment was too low. After collecting 153 responses, we therefore reduced the sample size from 660 to 450 and increased the subject payments from $0.30 to $0.50. The data for the original 153 participants were not accessed or downloaded from Qualtrics during this discussion. This decision was based off of the slowness of data collection, suggesting our subject compensation was too small to be of interest to participants.

question.value: Participants will be recruited via a study posting on Amazon Mechanical Turk. The study posting will include a link to a Qualtrics study. White American adults (18 years or older) will be eligible for participation. Participants will be compensated with $0.50 for their participation.

q11.value: 450 participants will be collected in the study. See Explanation of Existing Data for more information.

q12.value: A power analysis using G*Power  determined that a sample size of N = 328 participants would be needed to obtain power of .95 to detect a small effect of .20, to examine differences between two groups.

question.value:
The study will use a between-subjects design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a self-affirmation or control condition. Following the same procedure adopted in other studies (e.g., Badea, Bender, & Korda, 2020), all participants will be given a list of values (listed below) and will rank-order the values from most to least importance to them. Those in the self-affirmation condition will write about the value they identified as most important; those in the control condition will write about the value least important to them. 

The self-affirmation values and domains include: artistic skill, athletics, business/money, creativity, independence, music, relationships, religious values, sense of humor, politics, and spontaneity

Outgroup attitudes. Participants will be asked to provide their attitudes toward Muslims. Following Amiot and Hornsey (2010), participants will first be given feeling thermometers (e.g., 0 to 100, cold/warm, unfriendly/friendly, distant/close, different/similar) and asked to indicate the amount of warmth they feel toward Muslims. Then, participants will be provided with a series of adjectives (i.e., intelligent, friendly, likeable, immature, cultivated, boring, talented, sympathetic, stubborn, trustworthy, bad, dishonest, truthful) and asked to indicate how they believe Muslims rank on each adjective (i.e., 1 = not at all; 9 = extremely). Negative adjectives will be reverse-coded, meaning that higher scores will indicate more positive ratings for Muslims. The feeling thermometers and adjectives will be standardized and combined to form a single index of attitudes toward Muslims. To mask the interest in collecting responses toward Muslims, participants will make feeling thermometer ratings toward 4 other religious categories (Christians, Hindus, Buddhists, & Atheists). Participants will also rate Christians and Atheists on the adjectives ratings. 

Intergroup anxiety. The Intergroup Anxiety scale (Stephan & Stephan, 1985) will measure negative emotions toward interacting with a group of Muslims (i.e., 0 = not at all, 9 = extremely). Participants will be asked to indicate the extent to which they feel each of six negative items (e.g., uncertain, worried, awkward, anxious, threatened, and nervous) and six positive items (e.g., comfortable, trusting, friendly, confident, safe, and at ease). Positive items will be reverse-coded, and items will be combined to form a measure of intergroup anxiety. 

Self-compassion. Self-compassion will be measured using the 12-item Self-Compassion Scale-Short Form (Raes, Pommier, Neff, & Van Gucht, 2011). An example item includes: “I try to see my failings as part of the human condition” and the scale is measured using a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Almost never, 5 = Almost always).

Additional demographics will also be collected (See Study1_Qualtrics_Measures.docx).

First, in a regression analysis, condition (1 = self-affirmation; 0 = control) will be examined as a predictor of outgroup prejudice. Then, to test the theoretical model depicted in Figure 1, the PROCESS macro (Version 3; Hayes, 2013) will be used to determine the parallel mediational influences of intergroup anxiety and self-compassion on outgroup prejudice.

q20.value: Participants will be excluded from analyses if they 1) answer zero of three attention checks correctly, 2) fail to answer one of the three manipulation checks correctly, 3) are identified as an outliers (defined as ±2.5 standard deviations above or below the mean of the outcome variable in a given analysis), 4) if they are not White American, or 5) if the IP address or MTurk ID number repeats with an additional participant in the dataset.

q21.value: Participants that fail to provide data on the self-affirmation manipulation, measures of prejudice, or measures of self-compassion or intergroup anxiety, will not be analyzed.

q22.value: Potential covariates (e.g., religious affiliation, gender, political orientation) may be explored for their influences on these relationships. For example, it could be speculated that religiosity (identifying as a religious person, identifying as a member of a certain religion) may influence prejudice ratings toward Muslims (a religious group).

q23.value: An original version of this study was preregistered and data collection began on 3/18/2020. The original sample size was 660 Ps paid $0.30 per participant on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Data collection was slow and suggested payment was too low. After collecting 153 responses, we therefore reduced the sample size from 660 to 450 and increased the subject payments from $0.30 to $0.50. The data for the original 153 participants were not accessed or downloaded from Qualtrics during this discussion. This decision was based off of the slowness of data collection, suggesting our subject compensation was too small to be of interest to participants.

Intergroup anxiety will mediate the relationship between self-affirmation and prejudice: those in the self-affirmation condition will show lower levels of intergroup anxiety as compared to those in the control condition, and higher levels of intergroup anxiety will be associated with higher levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis II).

Self-compassion will mediate the effect of self-affirmation on prejudice. Specifically, those in the self-affirmation condition will show higher levels of self-compassion as compared to those in the control condition; in addition, higher levels of self-compassion will be associated with lower levels of outgroup prejudice (Hypothesis III).

attributes.title: Reducing Prejudice through Self-Affirmation
attributes.description: Research suggests that self-affirmation can reduce threat in a multitude of domains (e.g., stereotype threat). Given the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce threats to the self of various types, the current work examines the capacity for self-affirmation to reduce outgroup prejudice, and the mechanisms which explain this effect.
attributes.withdrawal_justification:
Subject compensation was too small. See below for details.

Data collection began on 3/18/2020. The original sample size was 660 Ps paid $0.30 per participant on Amazon Mechanical Turk. Data collection was slow and suggested payment was too low. After collecting 153 responses, we therefore reduced the sample size from 660 to 450 and increased the subject payments from $0.30 to $0.50. The data for the original 153 participants were not accessed or downloaded from Qualtrics during this discussion. This decision was based off of the slowness of data collection, suggesting our subject compensation was too small to be of interest to participants.

A new preregistration will be submitted, and will indicate that the preregistration was taking place prior to human observation of the data.

attributes.title: The role that psychological factors play in opioid misuse in individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain
attributes.description: Chronic musculoskeletal pain is one of the most common forms of chronic pain. People with chronic musculoskeletal pain often consume opioids to alleviate their musculoskeletal symptoms. Psychological factors are essential factors in how an individual with chronic pain manages their pain experience.

q1.value: Javier Martinez-Calderon, Mar Flores-Cortes, Jose Miguel Morales-Asencio, Alejandro Luque-Suarez

q2.value: The aim of this systematic review will be to evaluate cross-sectional and longitudinal associations between psychological factors and opioid misuse in individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a systematic review of observational studies.

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We will search CINAHL, EMBASE, PsycINFO, and PubMed from inception up to April 2020. Eligibility Criteria The inclusion criteria will be: 1. Studies: observational studies (cross-sectional; case-control; cohort studies). 2. Participants: adults with chronic musculoskeletal pain. 3. Exposure: psychological factors such as self-efficacy, distress, fear, catastrophizing, among others. 4. Outcomes: opioid misuse in terms of opioid overdose, opioid misuse, substance addiction, or the presence of mortality as a consequence of opioids. The exclusion criteria will be: 1. Adults with chronic musculoskeletal pain because of surgery or fractures. 2. Studies with animals. Study Selection Potential articles will be screened with title and abstract. Then, we will screen the full-text if the study selection is unclear after reading the title and abstract. We will resolve any disagreements via consensus or a third reviewer, if required. Data Extraction The following information will be extracted from every included study: study (year and country) and participant characteristics (age, sex, musculoskeletal pain location, and pain duration); setting; psychological factors details; opioid details; and main findings of every included study. Any disagreements were resolved via consensus.

q11.value: Individuals with chronic musculoskeletal pain. We will not calculate the sample size because the present study will be a systematic review design.

question.value:
Exposure: any psychological factors related to opioid misuse. 

Outcomes: opioid misuse.

We plan to conduct meta-analyses of effect estimates for the association between psychological factors and opioid misuse. Meta-analyses will be divided by psychological factors and outcomes (e.g. fear and opioid overdose). If meta-analyses cannot be carried out, for example, due to a huge heterogeneity across the included studies, we will summarise data using a narrative synthesis. We will use the QUIPS tool to evaluate the risk of bias of longitudinal studies. We will use the Newcastle Ottawa Scale to evaluate the risk of bias in case-control studies. We will use the modified Newcastle Ottawa Scale to evaluate the risk of bias in cross-sectional studies. We will use the GRADE approach to assess the certainty of the evidence.

attributes.title: A systematic review of clinical practice guidelines for recurrent miscarriage
attributes.description: The aim of this systematic review is to identify, appraise and describe published CPGs for the management, investigation and/or follow-up of RM within high-income countries.

summary.value: This registration contains Extended Data for the systematic review protocol, published on HRB Open Research, i.e. Supplementary Files 1-3: (1) PRISMA-P checklist; (2) Sample search strategy; (3) Data extraction template.

registration_responses.summary: This registration contains Extended Data for the systematic review protocol, published on HRB Open Research, i.e. Supplementary Files 1-3: (1) PRISMA-P checklist; (2) Sample search strategy; (3) Data extraction template.
